questions.question: Which of the following viruses is related to etiology of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
What is nasopharyngeal carcinoma also known as?
questions.explanation: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also known as Guangdong tumor. This is because the SouthernChinese province of Guangdong has the highest prevalence of the tumor.Chinese, especially from southeastern China (Canton), have a higher genetic susceptibility tonasopharyngeal cancer (NPC). Chinese emigrants are also genetically more susceptible, however,the susceptibility falls in subsequent generations.Other South-East Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and people of Mongoloid originare also more susceptible.

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinomain high-risk populations of China?
questions.explanation: Human papillomavirus is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma inhigh-risk populations of China. EBV (Epstein Barr virus) causes nasopharyngeal carcinoma.HPV(Human papillomavirus) causes inverted papilloma of the nose.High-risk populations such as the Chinese have a very high incidence of nasopharyngealcarcinoma. The following factors have been implicated in the pathogenesis:• Burning of incense or wood (polycyclic hydrocarbons)• Consumption of preserved salted fish (nitrosamines)• Vitamin C deficient diet (vitamin C blocks nitrosification of amines and is thus protective)511

questions.question: A patient with a family history of nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with nasal dischargeand a painless lump in the upper neck. On posterior rhinoscopy, where will you mostcommonly expect to find a mass originating from?
questions.explanation: The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.Structures seen in nasopharynx-Torus tubarius-Pharyngeal tonsil-Pharyngeal recess(Fossa of Rosenmuller)- Pharyngealopening ofeustachian tubeFold overlying Passavant's ridgeOMARROW

questions.question: What is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature ofnasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by-• Hearing loss• Nasal obstruction.Epistaxis• Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all thecranial nerves.•Headache• Earache•Neck pain• Weight loss

questions.question: A housewife from rural Tripura with a past history of infectious mononucleosis presents withcomplaints of double vision and a neck swelling that has progressively increased in size. Shealso gives a history of nasal discharge and is annoyed that her husband is recentlycomplaining of a change in her voice. What is the most likely speech pattern observed here?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario of exposure to EBV, progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, nasaldischarge, diplopia (involvement of cranial nerve VI), and change in voice is suggestive ofnasopharyngeal carcinoma. The most likely speech pattern, in this case, is rhinolalia clausa ordenasal speech, due to obstruction of the nasopharynx by the tumor.512Rhinolalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words resonated in the nasal cavity and isusually seen due to blockage of nose or nasopharynxOther nasal symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma are:• Nasal obstruction• Nasal discharge.• EpistaxisOption B- Rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal voice) is seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency.Option C- Puberphonia is the persistence of prepubertal voice into adolescence or adulthood.Option D- Muffled and thick speech, often called "hot potato voice" is seen in peritonsillar abscessor quinsy.

questions.question: A 45-year-old Chinese woman presents with left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and left-sided hearing loss. What is the most likely cause for hearing loss in this case?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hearing loss, in this case, is due to serous otitis media. Serous otitis media is caused due to mechanical obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal growth.

questions.question: 508You have sent a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma and hearing loss for tympanometry.Which of the following tympanometry curves do you expect to find?
questions.explanation: Type B tympanometry curve is expected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Due to mechanicalobstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor, serous otitis media occurs, causing conductivehearing loss.

questions.question: You are an ENT resident on a clinical elective in Guangzhou. You receive a patient withpainless cervical lymphadenopathy, conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facialpain. Which of the following do you see here?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter's triad/Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter'ssyndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.Trotter's triad consists of:• Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.• Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigeminalnerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain.• Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CNX) which presents as palatalasymmetry.Option A - Samter's triad seen in ethmoidal polyps consists of nasal polypi, asthma, and Aspirinintolerance513Option C van der Hoeve syndrome is seen in otosclerosis consists of osteogenesis imperfecta,otosclerosis, and blue scleraOption D Kartagener syndrome consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliarydyskinesia.

questions.question: Which of the following branches of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter's triad?
questions.explanation: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter's triad. Trotter's triad seenin nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It consists of:• Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.•• Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigeminalnerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain.• Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.

questions.question: A known case of right-sided nasopharyngeal carcinoma now presents with drooping ofeyelids, reduced sweating on the right side of the face, and constricted pupil. Involvement ofwhich of the following structures leads to these features?
questions.explanation: Involvement of the sympathetic chain causes these features. The given clinical scenario issuggestive of Horner's syndrome secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma involving the cervicalsympathetic chain.Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and ipsilateral anhydrosis.Option B - Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) involvement presents as ipsilateral temporoparietalneuralgia.Option C-Cranial nerve VI (Abducens nerve) involvement causes ophthalmoplegiaOption D - Jugular foramen involvement causes paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, causingjugular foramen syndrome, also seen in acoustic neuroma and glomus jugulare.

questions.question: Which of the following WHO categories does differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cellcarcinoma of the nasopharynx belong to?
questions.explanation: Differentiated non-keratinized squamous cell carcinoma is categorized as Type 2.WHO Classification based on Histopathology:Note- The latest WHO classification has combined types 2 and 3 into one category:Non-keratinizing Squamous cell carcinoma which is further subclassified into differentiated andnon-differentiated types.TypeHistopathological categoryTypeKeratinizing Squamous cell cIarcinoma (SCC)514TypeTypeIIHistopathological categoryNon-keratinizing Squamous cell carcinomaBasaloid squamous cell carcinoma is a rare subtype of epithelial cancer seen in thenasopharyngeal area. It was included alongside the above classification from 2005. It is known forits aggressive clinical progression and poor chances of survival.

questions.question: A patient with persistent cervical lymphadenopathy now came with spontaneous epistaxis.Nasal endoscopy showed a mass arising from the fossa of Rosenmuller. Biopsy from the massrevealed a keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. What is the treatment of choice in thiscase?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The treatment of choice isradiotherapy.Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regionaldisease is invariably radiotherapy.Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.Stage III and IV are treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can beneoadjuvant, concurrent, or adjuvant to radiotherapy.515
